This is a 62-year-old Hispanic male – let's call him Martin.


Martin is trying to sleep. But he's rolling around in bed, sleepless.

Martin is the exact kind of person that journalists would have no excuse to talk to. He doesn't have a job. He doesn't have a wife or partner. He doesn't have children in his home. He's just a regular guy in his 60s who doesn't interact with that many people. But we know a little bit about Martin because he recorded everything he did for one day in 2021.¹ And even with this small bit of information, these are potential red flags – because he could be missing something critical to human survival: friends, family, acquaintances – in short, social bonds. Humans evolved to survive in groups, whether that's gathering food or fighting off predators. Without those connections, our bodies sound the alarm with pain. "Feelings of loneliness told them when those protective bonds were endangered or deﬁcient," wrote neuroscientist John Cacioppo. "What’s missing when you’re lonely is the feeling of closeness, trust, and the affection of genuine friends, loved ones, and community," writes former US surgeon general Vivek Murthy in his 2020 book, Together. "When we feel lonely, we’re unhappy and long to escape this emotional pain." We're no longer hunted by predators, but strong relationships are still a fundamental human need. Without those bonds, we feel more anxious, more fearful, and more stressed. Because thousands of years of evolution made us believe that when we're isolated, we're in danger.
¹ He did it for the American Time Use Survey, which has tracked how Americans spend their time since 2003.
Martin got out of bed and is watching TV.

It looks like Martin is fine for now.


Let's take a look at some more people.

The average human knows about 5,000 faces. We can put a name to about 1,500 of them, and we personally know about 500.¹ But most of those people won't help us in times of need, nor will they make us feel less isolated. The people who will help are our friends – and psychologist Robin Dunbar argues that we have an average of 150 people who we try to contact at least once a year.² Within that group, he found that we have 50 people who contact once every six month; 15 people we contact once a month; five people we contact once a week; and one to two people with whom we share "really intense relationships like romantic partners." (Often, women also have this kind of relationship with their "Best Friend Forever.") >> DUNBAR CHART – BUT COLOR WITH SAME THING WE'LL USE BELOW
¹ According to facial recognition research by Rob Jenkins at the University of York
² Dunbar argues that an animal's brain size limits the number of stable relationships we can maintain, and for humans it is 150. Recent studies argue that there is no empirical evidence for this limit. We won't solve this argument in a footnote, so just imagine this group as people you'd want to invite to your wedding.
So let's color code our friends and family with TKCOLOR and everyone else with TKCOLOR.

Everyone needs a different amount of social interaction. But according to the American Time Use Survey, the average American spends about 6 hours with friends or family each day. So let's track how many of these people interact with their friends or family for at least 6 hours a day. For the time spent with everyone else – acquaintances, coworkers, etc. – I'll give partial credit.¹ >> LEGEND ON SOCIAL INTERACTION
¹ A 2022 study of people's behavior during the Covid-19 pandemic found that people feel about 40% as psychologically close to acquaintances as they to do friends. This is admittedly not the most robust way to give partial credit for non-friends and family, but I couldn't find anything better.
Martin came home from the grocery store and he's preparing lunch.
After lunch, he decided to watch TV again. He's been around other people today, like at the grocery store. But he hasn't done anything with other people.

Lonely people report feeling more shy, more anxious, more negative, and more angry. They are less optimistic and have lower self esteem. Are they inherently different compared to everyone else? In a 2006 study, neuroscientist John Cacioppo and his colleagues hypnotized a bunch of college students to feel lonely. They told the subjects: “Think of a time in which you felt isolated. You felt lonely. Perhaps you felt like you just didn’t belong – that you had no friends.” After confirming the hypnotism worked, they found that the students who were made to be lonely reported the exact same negative feelings as people who were actually lonely. It confirmed some of his previous findings: Loneliness can find all of us. "We had demonstrated yet again that lonely individuals are not a breed apart," Cacioppo wrote in his book, Loneliness. "Any of us can succumb to loneliness, and along with it, all the other characteristics that travel as its entourage."

The American Time Use Survey, which this story is based on, is interesting because we see parts of people's lives that would never make it into a newspaper – or even social media. And what we see is a quiet epidemic. Over the last few decades, we're spending more time alone, and less time with friends and family. The amount of time we spend with family has drastically decreased across every age group: >> FAMILY CHART And the amount of time we spend with friends has plummeted: >> FRIENDS CHART Meanwhile, the amount of time we spend alone has gone up across every age group: >> AGE GROUP CHART Being alone isn't necessarily the same as being lonely. But according to a meta-analysis of studies, more people have reported feeling lonely every year since 1976. Then the pandemic came along. It supercharged our loneliness.
As you can see, most people have barely had an hour of social interaction on this day – and this is a weekend day!

Every so often, the American Time Use Survey asks people a question that gets at how well someone is doing. The last time it was asked was 2021. The question goes something like this:
Imagine a ladder. The top of the ladder is your best possible life. The bottom is your worst possible life. Which step of the ladder do you feel you personally stand at the present time?
This is called the Cantril ladder, and in the US most people answer fairly positively – on average, people say they are a 7 out of 10. Pause for a second and ask yourself where you are on this ladder: >> CHART: CANTRIL LADDER

Martin is still watching TV.


When Martin was asked where he is on the Cantril ladder, he said zero – living his worst possible life.


He'll keep watching TV until around 8:30pm and then go to sleep.
Let's look at where everyone else is on the Cantril ladder. I'll sort them so we can see it better.

The day is almost over, and we can clearly see a trend.


People lower on the ladder are far more likely to have gone a full day being mostly isolated.

Loneliness robs you of your best self. Research has shown that isolated people are less generous with donations, less likely to persevere in the face of adversity, more likely to procrastinate, and more likely to administer harsher punishments.¹ Lonely people get lower quality sleep. And it may predict the progression of Alzheimer's disease. Ultimately, lonely people are 50% more likely to die prematurely than people with strong social connections – the equivalent of having six alcoholic drinks a day or smoking 15 cigarettes a day.
¹ From Cacioppo's book, Loneliness

When we see people cry out for help, it often looks like they are unable to manage their emotions. Sometimes we assume they are unpleasant people who don't deserve company. We ostracize them. So when we are lonely, we hide it. We crawl deeper into our shells because we feel weak and vulnerable. When we're lonely, we become even more wary of social threats, so the very thing we need – social interaction – feels dangerous. We start to blame ourselves; we wonder if something really is wrong with us. "Over time," Murthy writes, "this vicious cycle may convince us we don’t matter to anyone and that we’re unworthy of love."

Experts have said we are experiencing an "epidemic of loneliness."


But I'm worried that this epidemic is invisible. 


We don't share that we are lonely. We treat it like an individual problem, not a structural one. After all, if people don't have what they need – food, shelter, money – we often tell them it's their own damn fault.


Yet more and more people are feeling the pain of isolation. Sure, you could say more and more people are at fault. But what if we've created a world that tells people they aren't worthy of love?

The way stories about loneliness usually end is by prescribing a fix. There are some smart people who have thought of good ideas. For example:

I started looking into the American Time Use Survey because I wanted to know what helps us be happy. This project was literally called "Happy Days". Then I started looking at individuals in this dataset – what they did on their diary day, how they responded to the survey, and who they spent their time with. And after learning about people like Martin, all I wanted to do was somehow tell them: You are worthy of love – and that, even in this small way, I see you.
